dublinCore.dc:title: 115 HR 5619 IH: Emergency Port of Entry Personnel and Infrastructure Funding Act of 2018
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. O'Rourke (for himself and Ms. Stefanik) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Homeland Security, and in addition to the Committees on Ways and Means, and Appropriations, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To provide emergency funding for port of entry personnel and infrastructure, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Emergency Port of Entry Personnel and Infrastructure Funding Act of 2018.

paragraph.text: The term Administrator means the Administrator of the General Services Administration.
The term Commissioner means the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection.
The term Northern border means the international border between the United States and Canada.
The term relevant committees of Congress means—

subparagraph.text: the Committee on Environment and Public Works of the Senate;
the Committee on Finance of the Senate;
the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate;
the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate;
the Committee on Homeland Security of the House of Representatives;
the Committee on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives; and
the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives.

paragraph.text: The term Secretary means the Secretary of Homeland Security.
The term Southern border means the international border between the United States and Mexico.

section.header: U.S. customs and border protection personnel

paragraph.text: In addition to positions authorized before the date of the enactment of this Act and any existing officer vacancies within U.S. Customs and Border Protection on such date, the Secretary, subject to the availability of appropriations for such purpose, shall hire, train, and assign to duty, by not later than September 30, 2023—

subparagraph.text: 5,000 full-time U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers to serve on all inspection lanes (primary, secondary, incoming, and outgoing) and enforcement teams at United States land ports of entry on the Northern border and the Southern border; and
350 full-time support staff for all United States ports of entry.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may waive any limitation on the number of full-time equivalent personnel assigned to the Department of Homeland Security in order to carry out paragraph (1).

Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit to the relevant committees of Congress a report that includes a plan for ensuring the placement of sufficient U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers on outbound inspections, and adequate outbound infrastructure, at all Southern border land ports of entry.

Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, shall submit to the relevant committees of Congress a report that contains plans for the Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Agriculture, and the Department of Health and Human Services, respectively, for ensuring the placement of sufficient U.S. Customs and Border Protection agriculture specialists, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service entomologist identifier specialists, Food and Drug Administration consumer safety officers, and other relevant and related personnel at all Southern border land ports of entry.
Not later than one year after the date of the enactment of this Act and annually thereafter, the Secretary shall submit to the relevant committees of Congress a report that—

subparagraph.text: details the Department of Homeland Security’s implementation plan for the staff enhancements required under subsection (a)(1)(A);
includes the number of additional personnel assigned to duty at land ports of entry, classified by location;
describes the methodology used to determine the distribution of additional personnel to address northbound and southbound cross-border inspections; and
includes—

clause.text: the strategic plan required under section 5(a)(1);
the model required under section 5(b), including the underlying assumptions, factors, and concerns that guide the decision-making and allocation process; and
the new outcome-based performance measures adopted under section 5(c).

subsection.text: The Secretary shall ensure that each U.S. Customs and Border Protection officer is equipped with a secure 2-way communication and satellite-enabled device, supported by system interoperability, that allows U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers to communicate—

paragraph.text: between ports of entry and inspection stations; and
with other Federal, State, tribal, and local law enforcement entities.

subsection.header: Border area security initiative grant program
subsection.text: The Secretary shall establish a program for awarding grants for the purchase of—

paragraph.text: identification and detection equipment; and
mobile, hand-held, 2-way communication devices for State and local law enforcement officers serving on the Southern border.
The Commissioner may aid in the enforcement of Federal customs, immigration, and agriculture laws by—

subparagraph.text: designing, constructing, and modifying—

clause.text: living quarters for officers, agents, and personnel;
technology and equipment, including technology and equipment deployed in support of standardized and automated collection of vehicular travel time; and
other structures and facilities, including structures and facilities owned by municipalities, local governments, or private entities located at land ports of entry;

subparagraph.text: acquiring, by purchase, donation, exchange, or otherwise, land or any interest in land determined to be necessary to carry out the Commissioner’s duties under this section; and
constructing additional ports of entry along the Southern border and the Northern border.

paragraph.text: In selecting improvements under this section, the Commissioner, in coordination with the Administrator, shall give priority consideration to projects that will substantially—

subparagraph.text: reduce commercial and passenger vehicle and pedestrian crossing wait times at one or more ports of entry on the same border;
increase trade, travel efficiency, and the projected total annual volume at one or more ports of entry on the same border; and
enhance safety and security at border facilities at one or more ports of entry on the same border.

paragraph.header: Locations for new ports of entry
paragraph.text: The Secretary shall consult with the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Agriculture, the Secretary of State, the International Boundary and Water Commission, the International Joint Commission, and appropriate representatives of States, Indian tribes, local governments, and property owners, as appropriate, to—

subparagraph.text: determine locations for new ports of entry; and
minimize adverse impacts from such ports on the environment, historic and cultural resources, commerce, and the quality of life of the communities and residents located near such ports.

paragraph.text: Nothing in this subsection may be construed to—

subparagraph.text: create any right or liability of the parties described in paragraph (1);
affect the legality or validity of any determination by the Secretary under this Act; or
affect any consultation requirement under any other law.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, if the Secretary determines that the acquisition of a leasehold interest in real property and the construction or modification of any facility on such leased property are necessary to facilitate the implementation of this Act, the Secretary may—

paragraph.text: acquire such leasehold interest; and
construct or modify such facility.

subsection.text: There is authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section, for each of the fiscal years 2018 through 2023, $1,000,000,000, of which $5,000,000 shall be used for grants authorized under subsection (d).

subsection.header: Offset, rescission of unobligated Federal funds

paragraph.text: There is hereby rescinded, from appropriated discretionary funds that remain available for obligation on the date of the enactment of this Act (other than the unobligated funds referred to in paragraph (4)), amounts determined by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget that are equal, in the aggregate, to the amount authorized to be appropriated under subsection (h).
The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall determine and identify—

subparagraph.text: the appropriation accounts from which the rescission under paragraph (1) shall apply; and
the amount of the rescission that shall be applied to each such account.

paragraph.text: Not later than 60 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall submit to Congress and to the Secretary of the Treasury a report that describes the accounts and amounts determined and identified under paragraph (2) for rescission under paragraph (1).
This subsection shall not apply to unobligated funds of—

subparagraph.text: the Department of Defense;
the Department of Veterans Affairs; or
the Department of Homeland Security.

section.header: Implementation of Government Accountability Office findings

paragraph.text: The Secretary, in consultation with the Commissioner, the Administrator of the Federal Highway Administration, State departments of transportation, and other public and private stakeholders, shall develop a strategic plan for standardized collection of vehicle wait times at land ports of entry.
The strategic plan required under paragraph (1) shall include—

subparagraph.text: a description of how U.S. Customs and Border Protection will ensure standardized manual wait time collection practices at ports of entry;
current wait time collection practices at each land port of entry, which shall also be made available through existing online platforms for public reporting;
the identification of a standardized measurement and validation wait time data tool for use at all land ports of entry; and
an assessment of the feasibility and cost for supplementing and replacing manual data collection with automation, which should utilize existing automation efforts and resources.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall update the strategic plan required under paragraph (1) to reflect new practices, timelines, tools, and assessments, as appropriate.

subsection.text: The Secretary, in consultation with the Commissioner and State, municipal, and private sector stakeholders at each port of entry, shall develop a standardized model for the allocation of U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers and support staff at land ports of entry, including allocations specific to field offices and the port level that utilizes—

paragraph.text: current and future operational priorities and threats;
historical staffing levels and patterns; and
anticipated traffic flows.

The Secretary, in consultation with the Commissioner and relevant public and private sector stakeholders, shall identify and adopt not fewer than two new, outcome-based performance measures that support the trade facilitation goals of U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

paragraph.header: Effect of trusted traveler and shipper programs
paragraph.text: Outcome-based performance measures identified under this subsection should include—

subparagraph.text: the extent to which trusted traveler and shipper program participants experience decreased annual percentage wait time compared to nonparticipants; and
the extent to which trusted traveler and shipper program participants experience an annual reduction in percentage of referrals to secondary inspection facilities compared to nonparticipants.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may not adopt performance measures under this subsection that—

subparagraph.text: solely address U.S. Customs and Border Protection resource efficiency; or
fail to adequately—

clause.text: gauge the impact of programs or initiatives on trade facilitation goals; or

paragraph.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit to the relevant committees of Congress a report that identifies—

subparagraph.text: the new performance measures developed under this subsection; and
the process for the incorporation of such measures into existing performance measures.
